div.head: Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1930
div.p: On 24 July 1930, Sotheby & Co. held an important sale of Ruskinʼs literary remains, described in the sale catalogueʼs title as the Catalogue of the Manuscripts and Remaining Library of John Ruskin, Removed from His Residence, Brantwood, Coniston, and Sold with the Consent of Arthur Severn, Esq., and of His Trustees. This sale was perhaps the single most consequential event for the provenance of the early manuscripts.

div.head: Books from Ruskinʼs Library
div.p: The first 109 lots of the sale contained items from Ruskinʼs library, of which more than half (lots 24–83) was devoted to the “Kate Greenaway Collection from Brantwood”, while the remainder ranged from illuminated manuscripts and incunabula to modern first editions and presentation copies. Sothebyʼs must have anticipated that the Greenaway collection would command interest, having devoted four of the six plates in the illustrated catalogue to drawings from her books, as compared with only two plates showing Ruskin manuscripts. The expectation was justified, as indicated by a copy of the sale catalogue at the Beinecke Library that was annotated by an observer. Almost every lot in Greenaway collection found a buyer, with the highest price of £420 paid for a collection of autograph letters from Greenaway to Ruskin.

Among the books unrelated to Greeanway, a copy of William Blakeʼs illustrated edition of Youngʼs Night Thoughts, its engravings “coloured by the artist himself”, fetched £400 from the Maggs Bros. firm. Otherwise, according to the annotator of the Beinecke copy of the sale catalogue, the rare book and manuscript dealers, Maggs and Bernard Quaritch, acquired a few of the manuscript volumes and modern illustrated volumes, while other lots either were left unsold or their buyers unrecorded by the annotator. The Beinecke copy of the catalogue fails to note, for example, two items of incunabula as well as two lots of Walter Scott novels that, according to James S. Dearden, were purchased by J. H. Whitehouse (Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge and Brantwood, 49; and see Sotheby & Co., Catalogue of the Manuscripts and Remaining Library of John Ruskin, 14, 15-16 [lots 84, 89; and of the five available lots of Scott novels, 96-100, apparently only lots 96 and 100, which Whitehouse singled out perhaps because the catalogue mentions these as containing annotations by Ruskin).

div.head: Manuscripts from Ruskinʼs Library
div.p: The Ruskin manuscript portion of the sale was advertised in the catalogue as the “Ruskin Manuscripts from Brantwood: A large and highly important collection of autograph letters, diaries, note-books, poems, etc., including the original manuscript notes and sketches for ‘The Stones of Venice’, ‘Fors Clavigera’, ‘Praeterita’, and numerous other works, extending from 1827 to the end of Ruskinʼs working life in 1889” (Sotheby & Co., Catalogue of the Manuscripts and Remaining Library of John Ruskin, 18). The sale was divided into lots 110–22, of which the following pertain to the contents of ERM.

list.item:
Lot 110, “Letters to His Father, John James Ruskin”, items 1–6 as numbered in the catalogue.
Each item of the six consists of a 4o blue‐morocco and gilt binding containing letters. Item 1, the first volume, entitled in the catalogue as “Early Poems”, corresponds to MS XI. The catalogue description does not mention that W. G. Collingwood had assigned a roman‐numeral designation to this collection in his “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” (see History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Ruskin Manuscripts; and System of Title Citation for Manuscripts); and indeed, while Collingwoodʼs 1891 description of MS XI as an “envelope containing collected loose papers” had been updated in the Library Edition as “now [in 1903] bound up in a volume of letters and poems” (Ruskin, Works, 2:534), even that description had become inaccurate by 1930, owing to rebinding (see MS XI: Description). That this first volume of the six in lot 110 includes at least a portion of the items that had been contained in Collingwoodʼs “envelope” is clear from the catalogue description of “Early Poems (8), beginning with ‘Look at that Ship’, dated Feb. or March, 1828, when Ruskin was nine years old”, along with 137 letters, 1829–59.

Lot 112, “Early Poems and Juvenilia”, items I–VI, as numbered in the catalogue.
Each of the six items consists of a blue‐morocco slipcase, which contained manuscripts as follows. (The slipcases are not described individually in the catalogue, but they remain along with their original contents at the Beinecke Library; however, since the 1990s, the manuscripts have been stored apart from their respective slipcases, in order to guard against wear.) As the catalogue acknowledges (p. 20), its descriptions of the manuscripts rely on Collingwoodʼs “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” in Poems (1891) (see History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Ruskin Manuscripts; and System of Title Citation for Manuscripts), citing Collingwoodʼs roman‐numeral designations for the respective manuscripts, and adopting condensed versions of his descriptions of the contents (items I.1–3, 5; II–V). Only the physical descriptions of size and bindings are additions to Collingwoodʼs “Note” and original to Sothebyʼs. It is noteworthy in context of rare‐book and manuscript dealing that Collingwoodʼs edition was treated as the authoritative, or at least the most accessible, bibliographical source, while the Library Edition was not mentioned in the catalogue, although the latter must have been used to document item VI and perhaps item I.4, both of which Collingwoodʼs “Note” omits.
Item I, a slipcase, HARRY & LUCY | POEMS | &c, containing manuscripts 1–5 as numbered in the catalogue.

Given the existence of this slipcase at the time the catalogue was compiled, the three notebooks can be presumed to be the same as the manuscripts now associated with that slipcase in the Beinecke Library, as follows. As in item I.4 above, the catalogue does not draw on existing descriptions that were available in the Library Edition, although admittedly the reference is rather deeply buried in the bibliography volume (Ruskin, Works, 38:206). The catalogue describes the notebooks as a group: “74–84–84 pp. containing geological, historical and grammatical notes, half roan, 6 × 4 in.” This summary of the contents credibly, if only roughly, corresponds to the Latin grammar, mineralogy, travel itineraries, and sermon drafts in fact contained in these manuscripts. div.head: The Buyers
div.p: While the Greenaway collection and some of the rarer library items caught buyersʼ interest, it was the Ruskin manuscripts reserved for the second half of the sale that commanded the highest prices, according to the notations in the Beinecke copy of the catalogue. Prices ranged from £440 for the manuscript of The Stones of Venice, to £520 for a collection of Ruskinʼs letters to his father, to £1,600 for Ruskinʼs diaries. The Stones manuscript and the diaries were acquired by Whitehouse, who spent a total of £2,089 at the sale, thus assuring that his collection, Dearden writes, held "its position at the head of Ruskin collections" (Ruskin, Bembridge and Brantwood, 55).

Whitehouse had competitors, however, who adopted an alternative strategy to seeking high-profile items such as the diaries and manuscripts of the better-known Ruskin works. The Boston bookseller and collector, Charles E. Goodspeed, who had long been supplying American collectors with Ruskin first editions, had previously "found no competition" in London for the hundreds of Ruskin items beyond the typical antiquarian dealer's core of first-edition (or earlier edition) volumes of Modern Painters, Seven Lamps, and Stones (Goodspeed, Yankee Bookseller, 263; and see Charles E. Goodspeed [1867–1950]). Goodspeed took the same approach at the 1930 Sotheby's sale, assisted by B. F. Stevens and Brown as his agent. Whereas Whitehouse's manuscript acquisitions were canonical by the standards of the time--the diaries, the Stones manuscript, and lot 119, which was headed by manuscript for Ruskin's Turner Catalogue--Goodspeed targeted very early and very late works: for example, manuscripts of The King of the Golden River (lot 114, £155), a portion of Fors Clavigera (lot 118, £50), and Praeterita (£155). His strategy is consistent with the biographical bias animating collectors of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, who aspired to comprehensive ownership of every published item by their modern authors of choice, from juvenilia to last works (see The Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries; and see Catalogue of the Manuscripts and Remaining Library of John Ruskin, 21, 24-25).

In his 1937 autobiography, Goodspeed mentions that he acquired the King, Fors, and Praeterita manuscripts, and that he kept the Praeterita manuscript for himself, selling the other two (Yankee Bookseller, 267). Evidence at the Beinecke Library shows that his buyer for the King and Fors manuscripts was Yale University Library, and that the transfer was quick, sold in early November 1930. Evidence also reveals that Goodspeed's agent acquired additional manuscripts on his behalf at the 1930 sale, which, although Goodspeed fails to mention the items in his autobiography, he also sold to Yale University Library on the same date: Proserpina (lot 117, £30); miscellaneous notebooks, mostly on literary, historical, and geological topics (lot 122, £38); an assortment of Oxford lectures, lectures on the Val dʼArno, and a stray architectural notebook belonging to the 1850-51 Venice labors (lot 116, £70); and from the books portion of the sale, Ruskinʼs set of the Botanical Magazine, with his marginalia (lot 16). (Except for lot 16, all of these additional items are notated in the Beinecke copy of the Sothebyʼs catalogue as sold to B. F. Stevens & Brown, Goodspeed's agent; and the purchase of the Botanical Magazine is credited to Stevens & Brown by James Dearden in Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 48.)

The Beinecke at Yale also holds the contents of lots 110 and 112, the Ruskin family letters and the collection of juvenilia. How did these items come to Yale? According to the annotated sale catalogue at the Beinecke, the successful bids for these two lots were placed by “Allen” (lot 110, £520; lot 112, £260). This member of the George Allen family was probably Hugh Allen, whose role in the sale can be gathered from a letter by Ralph Brown of B. F. Stevens & Brown to J. H. Whitehouse on the occasion of the Severn Sale of Ruskin Effects, 1931: “we are having the benefit of the assistance of our friend Mr. Hugh Allen, and his help has been invaluable”, as compared with “the lack of interest shown by the Severn family in all matters pertaining to Ruskin” (quoted in Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 87). Beyond the initial purchase of lots 110 and 112 by Allen, however, the details of the manuscriptsʼ journey from London to New Haven are obscured by conflicting evidence.

According to Charles Beecher Hogan, lot 112 containing the twelve “little notebooks” of juvenilia were “purchased by Mr. Charles Goodspeed” when they were auctioned “en bloc at Sothebyʼs”, and “in turn" these items were "purchased by Yale”. It seems odd that Goodspeed would have commissioned two agents at the sale--Allen, as well as Stevens and Brown--unless, for some reason, Allen acted in concert with Stevens and Brown to obtain these two particular lots. Adding to the confusion, Hogan says that the volumes of letters (lot 110) “were purchased by Yale at the Sotheby auction of July 24, 1930”--a vague statement, suggesting either that Yale did not transact through Goodspeed for lot 110, or that Goodspeed's mediation is to be taken for granted by the reader. The latter assumption should have been forestalled by a footnote specifying that "other items that came from Brantwood, through Sotheby and Goodspeed" have been "marked with an asterisk". Hogan does not attach an asterisk to "the magnificent assemblage of Ruskin's letters" at Yale, leading one to the conclusion that Yale acquired the letters, lot 110, directly through the agency of Hugh Allen, while lot 112 came roundabout to Yale, from Allen to Goodspeed to the university library. Confidence in this chain of reasoning is shaken by Hogan's careless writing, however, since he also attributes "volumes" of Ruskin letters at Yale to an "auction at Sotheby's in 1936", leaving unclear whether he means that this sale accounted for all the bound volumes of letters or solely "five further volumes containing transcribed and typewritten copies that were collected by Messrs. Cook and Wedderburn during the preparation of their great edition of Ruskin's works" (Hogan, “Yale Collection of the Manuscripts of John Ruskin”, 62, 63).

When first acquired, these lots, in the eyes of the Yale curators, would have formed a unit tied together not only by their contents, which all relate to Ruskinʼs youth, but even by their blue‐morocco casings, which appear to be unique to these manuscripts. Whoever was originally responsible for this choice of bindings probably did perceive the manuscripts as forming a group, a perception likely founded in Collingwoodʼs bibliographical preparation for the Poems (1891) (see Provenance of Early Manuscripts at Denmark Hill and Brantwood.

The King of the Golden River manuscript cost this buyer almost as much as the rest, at £155. Goodspeed turned all this around to Yale for $3,000—throwing in, apparently as a kind of bonus, a collection of 47 autograph Ruskin letters, chiefly to Benjamin Jowett. The latter had no connection to the Sotheby sale that is detectable in the catalogue. These items acquired by Yale in November were sold at auction, according to the annotated sale catalogue at the Beinecke, to “Stevens B. F.” This is the firm of B. F. Stevens & Brown. Goodspeed mentions that this firm served as his agent in the 1931 sales (Goodspeed, Yankee Bookseller, 268), and the Beinecke holds correspondence between the proprietor, Ralph Brown, and Goodspeed starting in that year; as the evidence shows, however, the relationship reached back farther to the 1930 sale, if not earlier.

It was only a few years earlier, in 1927, that Ralph Brown had established what would prove a thirty‐year relationship with the important English Ruskin collector, J. H. Whitehouse (Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 43–44). In 1930, Whitehouse himself attended the Sothebyʼs sale and bid in his own name (Dearden, Ruskin, Bembridge, and Brantwood, 49), and so Stevens & Brown would have been free to work on commission for Goodspeed, if such was the arrangement. While there was doubtless rivalry between Goodspeed, Whitehouse, and other collectors, however, B. F. Stevens & Brown appears to have been bound to them by respect for Ruskin. A key figure in these relationships was Hugh Allen, who, on his death in August 1931, Brown remembered to Goodspeed as “our friend” and “a sad loss to Ruskin lovers as his knowledge and kindly interest was always at the disposal of those, who like himself, admired the great Victorian” (AL, Brown to Goodspeed, 29 August 1931).

It was who acquired lot 112, the juvenilia, at the 1930 sale. The provenance of lot 112 is not Hoganʼs only error; he also declares that the Proserpina manuscript and studies “were sold at Sothebyʼs on May 18, 1931, and came to Yale by purchase from Mr. Goodspeed” (Hogan, “Yale Collection of the Manuscripts of John Ruskin”, 67 n. 4). A part of this manuscript did come from the Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts, 1931 via Goodspeed, but the holding started with lot 117 from the 1930 sale, as explained above. the Red Books, from Goodspeed, it is possible that Goodspeed served as a conduit between Yale and Allen, in supplying the university library with both lots 112 and 110 from the Sothebyʼs sale. Whatever Goodspeedʼs involvement, if any, the lots came to Yale from Allen as a unit, as they are treated together in the earliest published report on Yaleʼs acquisitions from the July 1930 sale. Appearing in January 1931, the report treats the juvenilia along with the letters as a single “collection” (Weihe, “A Collection of Ruskin Manuscripts”). What remains enigmatic is that this published report makes no mention of the several items, including the King of the Golden River manuscript, which Goodspeed certainly did sell to the library the previous November.

Whomever or whatever interest Allen represented, his expenditure on lots 110 and 112 was significant, attesting to the value placed on these early manuscripts, presumably for their biographical interest. At £520, the letters fetched the second highest price of the manuscript lots after the £1,600 for the diaries, higher even than the £440 paid for the Stones of Venice materials. The £260 for the Red Books was significantly more than what B. F. Stevens paid for the King of the Golden River and the Praeterita manuscripts, at £155 and £166, respectively. Insofar as prices serve as a measure, manuscripts related to Ruskinʼs youth that the author referenced in the autobiography were valued more than the manuscript of the autobiography itself. (Goodspeed clung to the Praeterita manuscript, and treasured it, however; and it is interesting that, while prices for the late works were, not surprisingly, comparatively low, Hoganʼs 1942 article treated “the possession of the manuscripts of the Fors Clavigera and the Praeterita” as what “makes the Yale collection truly rich” [Hogan, “Yale Collection of the Manuscripts of John Ruskin”, 68].) It is possible, moreover, that the comparatively high prices for the early manuscripts was the effect not only of the interest in Ruskinʼs youth that the author himself had encouraged through his autobiographical writing, but also of the broader phenomenon of The Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries.
